subject: Politics
title: Bribery and Kickbacks
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Bribery and Kickbacks.

hook.text: A government official awards a contract to the highest briber, not the best bidder. Billions vanish this way yearly.

buildup.text: Bribery means paying officials for favorable treatment. Kickbacks return a portion of contracts to decision-makers.

discovery.text: The World Bank estimates that over $1 trillion in bribes is paid annually. Corruption costs more than foreign aid.

twist.text: Both sides benefit from bribery, so neither reports it. This makes corruption incredibly hard to detect and prove.

climax.text: Anti-bribery laws like the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act reach across borders. But enforcement is uneven.

punchline.text: Bribery is simple theft in a handshake. It robs the public to enrich the few.

quiz.question: Why is bribery so hard to detect?
options: Both parties benefit so neither reports it
Bribes are always paid electronically and traced easily
